utterance: Linsey Seitz: Hi, I'm Linsey Seitz. I'm an assistant professor at Northwestern, the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering. utterance: Linsey Seitz: Um I'll throw one thing out. One of the questions is, what are some promising strategies for controlling local chemical activity at electrodes? And so thinking about that local environment actually is something I've been quite interested in lately. So measuring and really quantifying the interaction relationship between bulk reactor scale conditions and local conditions, but then also really quantifying what local means for each experiment. So there's a number of different ways to measure local pH and folks have looked at cation impacts, proton impacts, kinetic isotope effects, but how local is local? So we're still really mostly if you're using these rotating disk electrode type formats, you're still measuring microns to millimeters away and we're really interested in that nanometer scale, right? So I think pushing experimental techniques to be able to probe those relevant length scales is kind of interesting.

annotations.ask question: The speaker poses a question about promising strategies for controlling local chemical activity at electrodes.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on their question by discussing the local environment, the interaction between bulk and local conditions, and the challenges of measurement at different scales.

utterance: Emily Carter: I completely agree.

annotations.supportive response: Expressing agreement, validation, or positive evaluation for other group members' contributions without adding new content.

utterance: Wilson Smith: Maybe to build off of that is, you know, to get the nanometer resolution, optimizing a reactor to characterize that, you know, in the context of what you're saying, Lindsey, which I agree, is like, you know, does the reactor we build to probe the spectroelectrochemical properties, does that relate to a bulk scale reactor? And I think to me that's one of the biggest challenges because you know, we had this discussion last time, there's certain conditions that you want to characterize in and there's very different conditions you want to use them in. So, you know, finding ways, you know, probably for spectroscopy, you want more of a bulk electrolyte to get signal to make everything stable and good, but most likely in a large scale reactor, you don't want bulk liquids flowing around these things. So to me that that's one of these challenges is how to devise a cell to really probe this nanometer locality. And I also agree how local is local, we ask that question like every day. I mean, local is all relative, but focusing on the nanometer scale, designing a cell for characterization that can give you nanoscale information that also represents a large scale reactor, I think that's a super important thing to do and a challenge that we need to work on.

annotations.develop idea: Wilson Smith is expanding on Linsey Seitz's idea about understanding local chemical activity at the nanometer scale, discussing the challenges of reactor design for nanoscale characterization.
annotations.identify gap: Wilson Smith identifies a gap in current capabilities, specifically the challenge of designing reactors that can effectively probe nanometer locality and provide nanoscale information representative of bulk-scale reactors.

utterance: Emily Carter: Actually, that brings up a really interesting point which I I'm just I'm ignorant, I don't know the answer to this. If you if you look at conventional commercial electrolyzers, are there different designs that are used in terms of, you know, whether or not they're yeah, I mean different obviously there are different reactor designs, right? And the question is, does that what does that depend on? Does it depend on Anyway, maybe Wilson, do you know something about this you could share with with us?

annotations.ask question: The speaker, Emily Carter, is requesting information about conventional commercial electrolyzers and their designs.
annotations.encourage participation: Emily Carter is directly asking Wilson if he knows something about the topic, inviting his participation and expertise.

utterance: Wilson Smith: Yeah, it's a really good question that opens up a Pandora's box. So if we look at, you know, some things we want to learn directly from water electrolysis and fuel cells. And in general, those electrochemical processes at scale typically don't ever have a bulk liquid electrolyte. They're all in the kind of membrane electrode assembly with humidified gas streams more or less. And the issue with translating that to CO2 reduction is that those systems have no problem with selectivity. They're unity selectivity either way. You're making hydrogen and oxygen out of water or the reverse process. Here for CO2 reduction, the sensitivity to selectivity is I think more paramount. And so in terms of reactor design, in general, we can see if you want to make a gaseous product, you probably want to have a membrane electrode assembly without a liquid. But if you want to make a liquid product, there's huge benefits to having a even a small flowing electrolyte which can use partial pressures and pull the liquid out. So this comes to, you know, separations, what are the steps we need to do afterwards? What what could be tolerant in the next step? You know, sometimes if we, you know, make formate and we have it in a bunch of electrolyte mixed in, well if we feed that to a biological process, that can withstand that. But if we send that to a thermochemical process, you need to do a separation step to to get that out. So, you know, the the the niceness that that field hasn't been explored yet is that there's so many options and that we don't really know. So I think that, you know, the reactor configuration at scale, we don't know what it will look like yet specifically for CO2 reduction chemistry. And there's some things that align with the water electrolyzers and some things that don't. So I think we need to learn from them but then also define design criteria for CO2 electrolyzers.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas by comparing CO2 reduction to water electrolysis and fuel cells, and discussing implications for reactor design.
annotations.ask question: The speaker is implicitly asking for more information or clarification on steps needed for separations and tolerance in the next steps.

utterance: Emily Carter: That's a that's a really good point. The other thing what you said got me thinking about is when you think about feeding the outcome of an of an electrolyzer, electrocatalyst, whatever, to a biological system that, you know, of course depending on the biological system, it could be faster, it could be slower. And so it brings up the issue of matching fluxes. And that's that is something that again, you know, we've had various discussions about complexity. This is another level of complexity is if you if you have multiple units that that have to to work together, how to match those fluxes in an optimal way.

annotations.Develop idea: Emily Carter is expanding on previous ideas by introducing the concept of matching fluxes as a level of complexity.
annotations.Acknowledge contribution: Emily Carter is acknowledging and building upon Wilson Smith's point.

utterance: Wilson Smith: Yeah, one one step further than that is, you know, so so totally how to match in terms of electricity, needing batteries to make these things run on the front end. The back end, do you need, you know, vats that that concentrate things and let it go. But the other thing that's relevant, you know, back to the kind of characterization question is the conditions that these things are run at. So for example, if we want a CO2 electrolyzer that makes syngas or CO, and we want to feed that to a Fischer-Tropsch synthesis plant which is operating at 50 bar, then the question is, do we need to operate the electrolysis at 50 bar so there's a direct connection? Which is the answer because thermodynamics says you don't want to make a gas then pressurize it.

utterance: Wilson Smith: I like I like in general the idea of alternative oxidative chemistries. So just pairing CO2 reduction with something that's other than water oxidation. The issues with selecting what you want to oxidize in this case methane has a lot of boundary conditions. So one would would say if you talk to an energy company and you say you want to do valorization of methane they take that as a signal to say well we can keep our methane infrastructure alive longer. And there's pros and cons to that so it's kind of it can enable one thing while addressing another. But it it comes into I think the systems integration which is super interesting because it's not just you know optimize CO2 reduction optimize methane oxidation put them together. There's there's integration issues of products or intermediates of one can cross over and oxidize or reduce at the other end making the system not stable. So I think in in looking at a different chemistry to pair with CO2 reduction on the anode side it's not just the efficiency or selectivity of that reaction but how the integration would work. You know if one works in a very alkaline system very very well and the other one prefers an acidic medium then you need good membrane selectivity or good electrolyte that reduces crossover. So I really like the idea of of a different oxidative chemistry but the pairing of it I think is is the key question rather than just the the efficiency of that one reaction.

annotations.propose new idea: Wilson Smith introduces the idea of exploring alternative oxidative chemistries to pair with CO2 reduction.
annotations.develop idea: He elaborates on the considerations and challenges of integrating CO2 reduction with methane oxidation or other chemistries.
annotations.identify gap: Wilson highlights the gap in current approaches regarding the integration of different chemistries with CO2 reduction, particularly concerning their compatibility.

utterance: Dr. Ben Carter: Yeah, me too. I was looking over the preliminary data last night, and there are some really interesting patterns, but also some confusing ones.

annotations.Supportive Response: The speaker expresses agreement and a positive evaluation of the preliminary data, indicating engagement with the discussion.

utterance: Dr. Aris Thorne: The confusing ones are what I'm interested in. Specifically, the anomaly in the protein folding simulation. It doesn't align with any of the existing models. I think that's where the novelty is.

annotations.identify gap: The speaker implies there's a gap in current knowledge or models since the anomaly in the protein folding simulation doesn't align with existing ones.

utterance: Dr. Kenji Tanaka: I agree, Aris. But we have to be careful not to chase a ghost. It could be a data artifact or a calibration error in the sensor array. Before we build a new theory, we need to be absolutely certain the data is robust.

annotations.critical response: The speaker is cautioning against interpreting the data without ensuring its robustness, suggesting potential flaws.
annotations.identify gap: The speaker is pointing out potential gaps or issues with the data, such as artifacts or calibration errors.

utterance: Dr. Lena Petrova: That's a fair point, Kenji. So, what's our first step to validate it? Ben, since you were looking at the raw data, do you have any ideas on how we could stress-test this particular anomaly?

annotations.ask question: Dr. Petrova is asking Ben for ideas on how to stress-test the anomaly.
annotations.acknowledge contribution: Dr. Petrova acknowledges Kenji's contribution by agreeing with his point.
annotations.process management: Dr. Petrova is guiding the discussion towards validating the anomaly.

utterance: Dr. Ben Carter: We could try running the simulation with a different set of initial parameters, ones that should theoretically prevent that fold from occurring. If it still shows up, that would suggest it's not a simple parameter-based error. I can start setting that up.

annotations.propose new idea: introducing a new approach to validate the anomaly observed

utterance: Dr. Aris Thorne: Great idea, Ben. While you do that, maybe Kenji and I can review the sensor calibration logs from that time period. Just to cover all our bases on the hardware side.

annotations.supportive response: Dr. Thorne expresses agreement and support for Dr. Carter's idea by offering to review the sensor calibration logs.
annotations.assign task: Dr. Thorne assigns a specific task to himself and Kenji, which is to review the sensor calibration logs from that time period.

utterance: Dr. Kenji Tanaka: Sounds like a plan.

annotations.supportive response: Dr. Tanaka expresses agreement with the proposed plan.

utterance: Dr. Lena Petrova: Perfect. Okay, let's move on to the second challenge then: the issue with the gene sequencing algorithm. Aris, I know you had some initial thoughts on this. Do you want to maybe share your screen and walk us through what you were thinking?

annotations.ask question: Dr. Petrova is explicitly asking Aris for their initial thoughts on the issue with the gene sequencing algorithm.
annotations.process management: Dr. Petrova is managing the meeting flow by transitioning to a new topic and inviting discussion.
annotations.clarify goal: Dr. Petrova is clarifying the objective of the next discussion segment, which is the issue with the gene sequencing algorithm.

utterance: Dr. Aris Thorne: Sure, one second. Okay, can everyone see my screen? So this is the output from the current algorithm. You can see here, in this region, the base-pair matching confidence drops significantly. My hypothesis is that the algorithm is overly sensitive to repetitive sequences, which are common in this sample. I've sketched out a potential modification to the weighting function here.

annotations.propose new idea: Dr. Thorne suggests a potential modification to the weighting function as a new approach to solve the algorithm's issue.
annotations.develop idea: Dr. Thorne explains his hypothesis about the algorithm's sensitivity to repetitive sequences and discusses a potential solution.

utterance: Dr. Ben Carter: That makes sense. Have you tried...

annotations.ask question: Dr. Ben Carter is requesting information or clarification on whether an attempt has been made to try something.
annotations.supportive response: Dr. Ben Carter acknowledges the previous statement by saying 'That makes sense'.

utterance: Dr. Kenji Tanaka: Before we modify the code, could we see the raw sequence data for that region? I want to see the repeats for myself.

annotations.ask question: Dr. Kenji Tanaka is requesting information or clarification on the raw sequence data for a specific region to see the repeats for himself.

utterance: Dr. Aris Thorne: Yep, pulling it up now.
